headline: Wall Street Journal Report on 1979 Tehran Hostage Crisis
summary: Wall Street Journal news item from Nov. 5, 1979, on the seizure of the U.S. embassy in Tehran and the taking of dozens of hostages.

headline: Iran-U.K. Relations
summary: See some events in the troubled history between Britain and Iran.

headline: Testing Cognitive Skills
summary: Pre-employment tests measure some cognitive abilities that are similar to those gauged by IQ tests and are used for selecting employees for many kinds of jobs.

summary: See an American Airlines document about its AAdvantage program.

headline: Where Jobs Can Be Found
summary: See the growth in middle-skill jobs from 2001 in Austin and other regions.

summary: Corrections & Amplifications for the edition of Nov. 29, 2011

summary: See an American Airlines document about flights and tickets.

summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Nov. 29, 2011

headline: The Big Number: 5
summary: Financial restatements have declined for five consecutive years among large U.S. companies, and they appear to be on track to decline again in 2011.

headline: Utility, Mayor Face Off in Japan
summary: Kansai Electric Power is likely to come under more pressure to reduce its use of nuclear power under new Osaka Mayor Toru Hashimoto.

headline: Think Tank Cuts Ireland's Growth Outlook
summary: Ireland's leading think tank slashed its growth outlook for the Irish economy and warned the euro area will plunge into a recession if the ECB fails to act.

headline: Syracuse Coach Explains Defense of Former Assistant
summary: Syracuse basketball coach Jim Boeheim defended his decision to initially support former assistant Bernie Fine, who was fired by the university Sunday amid allegations he sexually abused young boys.

headline: Witness Cites Her Dementia
summary: A key prosecution witness in the federal corruption case against New York City Councilman Larry Seabrook provided one of the trial's most jarring moments Tuesday when she told jurors Tuesday that she suffers from dementia.

headline: Rise in Autos Jobs Is Predicted
summary: Employment in the U.S. auto industry will increase by as much as 150,000 new jobs over the next four years, a leading industry research center said Tuesday.

headline: Deals India: Morning News Roundup
summary: News roundup from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Wednesday, November 30, 2011. Deals India has not verified the stories from other media organizations and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: Investors Sue Paramount Studios
summary: Viacom's Paramount Pictures was sued by Melrose Investors 2, which alleged the movie studio didn't share profits from nearly 30 films, including "Transformers" and "Mission: Impossible 3."

headline: FAA to Swiftly Step Up Safety Inspection of American Airlines, Affiliate
summary: Federal officials are stepping up safety inspections of American Airlines, including enhanced oversight of its maintenance practices and pilot training, in the wake of AMR's bankruptcy filing.

headline: Korean Industrial Output Shows Signs of Slowing
summary: South Korea's industrial output grew at a faster-than-expected rate in October, but underlying data pointed to slowing momentum for the export-dependent economy as the euro-zone fiscal crisis pushes the global economy closer to a full-blown slump.

headline: PICC Plans $786 Million Rights Issue
summary: PICC Property & Casualty, China's largest property insurer by revenue, plans to raise US$786 million from a deeply discounted rights issue aimed at bulking up its capital, with American International Group taking up all the shares it's entitled to buy.

headline: Cyber Sales Hit Record
summary: Online sales on Cyber Monday rose 22% to a record $1.25 billion. Meanwhile, for some retailers it is no longer just Cyber Monday—it is Cyber Week.

headline: Bill Eases U.S. Residency for Foreign Skilled Workers
summary: The House of Representatives passed a bill to make it easier for skilled workers to get green cards, a measure that particularly affects employers who want to hire Chinese and Indian nationals

headline: Mexico's Central Bank to Back Peso
summary: Mexico's central bank will begin selling dollars to support the peso on days the currency comes under heavy pressure, a move that shows how Europe's financial crisis is forcing even the most orthodox central banks to become more active in the markets.

headline: Sandusky-Founded Charity Seeks to Dismiss Suit
summary: A charity founded by former Penn State football coach Jerry Sandusky is seeking dismissal of a lawsuit that is attempting to prevent the nonprofit from transferring financial assets.

headline: Flint, Mich., Gets Emergency Manager
summary: Michigan's governor appointed Michael K. Brown, a former acting mayor of Flint, as its emergency manager, giving him broad powers to try to right the city's shaky finances.

headline: MF Trustee Seeks Third Funds Transfer
summary: The trustee liquidating the brokerage arm of MF Global sought to release a third wave of customer money that would return funds to clients who have yet to be reunited with their money, and get more back to other customers.

headline: GM: 'Small Number' of Volt Owners Want Loaners
summary: General Motors said a "small number" of Chevrolet Volt owners have asked for loaner vehicles while the auto maker and federal regulators investigate whether the cars are at risk of catching fire after a serious crash.

headline: Hill and Wihardja: Indonesia's Reform Reversal
summary: Foreign investors are piling in on promises of open markets, but the picture on the ground is far from rosy.

headline: Currency Hedge Funds' Miserable Year Extends In October
summary: Hedge funds are continuing to get hammered on currency trading as a tumultuous 2011 winds down, according to a widely followed performance index.

headline: Treasury Prices Pull Back
summary: Treasury bonds ended on a down note as some hopes to rescue the euro zone and a strong rebound in U.S. consumer confidence lured money into stocks.

headline: Euro Makes Modest Gains
summary: The euro moved in a narrow range above $1.33 as European leaders met to discuss potential resolutions to the debt crisis.

headline: MF's Holding Company to Dismiss Remaining Staffers
summary: The holding company of collapsed broker-dealer MF Global intends to dismiss 212 employees by year's end.

headline: Crude Higher as Iran Worries Rise
summary: Nymex crude futures settled just shy of $100 a barrel on escalating worries about oil production in the Middle East as well as on hopes that the U.S. economy is improving.

headline: Gold Futures Steady
summary: Gold prices settled higher, following the euro as currency trading set the tone in the precious-metals market.

headline: For the Jets, Not Many Happy Returns
summary: When someone other than Jim Leonhard catches a punt for the Jets, it often gets ugly.

headline: AMSC Slashes Work Force
summary: Wind turbine parts maker AMSC slashed its work force by an additional 20% in order to lower its cash usage as it works toward a return to profitability.

headline: GE Sees No Big AMR Exposure
summary: GE said it expected no "significant" impairment from bankruptcy filing by the parent of American Airlines, one of its largest customers.

headline: U.N. Climate Group Releases Weather Data
summary: The World Meteorological Organization said the global average temperature in 2011 was down from the record high in 2010 due to it being a La Nina year, but it was still higher than previous La Nina years.

headline: UnitedHealth Targets Double-Digit Growth
summary: UnitedHealth Group is targeting long-term earnings growth in a double-digit range as it aims to expand its Optum health-care-services business.

headline: Toyota to Sell Plug-In Prius in Japan
summary: Toyota said Tuesday it will launch a plug-in version of its popular Prius hybrid car on Jan. 30 in Japan with an annual sales target of 35,000 to 40,000 vehicles.

headline: European Stocks Finish Higher
summary: European stocks ended a bumpy session in the black, underpinned by stronger-than-expected U.S. consumer-confidence data, a well-received Italian bond auction and hope that euro-zone policy makers will make progress in tackling the region's debt crisis.

headline: NATO Condemns Serb Attack in Kosovo
summary: A top NATO officer condemned assaults by Serb crowds on soldiers in Kosovo as criminal acts, and the alliance pledged to defend its troops as violence flared anew.

headline: Conflict Over Water
summary: Brahma Chellaney takes issue with the review of his book "Water: Asia's New Battleground."

headline: Philip Bowring: The Coalition Against Chinese Hegemony
summary: To resist Beijing's maritime claims, Asean members will have to compromise and form a common front.

headline: Gome Profit Rises 24%
summary: Chinese retailer Gome Electrical Appliances said January-September net profit rose 24% from a year earlier due to higher sales, but it has canceled a property joint venture plan due to volatile market conditions .

headline: Google's Android Games Back in Korea
summary: Google resumed selling Android-based mobile-device games in South Korea, after accepting a remaining set of restrictions.

headline: Sentences Handed Down in Parmalat Case
summary: Banca ProfiloA Chairman Matteo Arpe and former Assicurazioni Generali Chairman Cesare Geronzi have been sentenced to three years and seven months and five years, respectively, in jail, in a trial related to the collapse of Parmalat.

headline: High Turnout in Second Day of Egypt Vote
summary: Voting was still going strong in Egypt Tuesday, the second and final day of the first round of elections, with long lines forming again at polling stations in the capital Cairo and other cities.

headline: Lost Altitude
summary: The parent company of American Airlines filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. See stock quotes, some key dates since 2002.

headline: FXall Ready For Quoting Euro Legacy Currencies
summary: Electronic foreign-exchange trading platform FXall has set up contingency plans to prepare for a potential euro breakup, and is advising clients to be ready to update their settlement instructions for additional currencies.

headline: Watson Wins FDA Approval for Contraceptive
summary: Watson Pharmaceuticals was granted Food and Drug Administration approval for its generic version of Bayer's Yaz birth-control pill.

headline: Air India to Sell and Lease Back Dreamliners
summary: Air India said its board has decided to lease out two Boeing 747-400s and some 777-200 long-range planes after it inducts the Boeing Dreamliner aircraft.

headline: South Africa GDP Disappoints
summary: South Africa's economy grew  a weaker-than-expected 1.4% in the third quarter compared with the preceding three-month period, further evidence that domestic labor strife and turmoil emanating from Europe are hampering Africa's largest economy.

headline: Nomura Sees EUR1T In Outflows If Euro-Zone Crisis Not Resolved
summary: Unless euro-zone leaders come up with a solution to the currency union's financial and fiscal woes, foreign investors could offload more than €1 trillion of euro-zone bonds in the coming months, Nomura warned in a research note dated Monday.

headline: New China Life Targets $695 Million in Shanghai IPO Tranche
summary: New China Life Insurance plans to raise up to $695 million from the Shanghai portion of its dual listing targeted to raise as much as $2.28 billion.

headline: India Faces Major Sugar Supply Gap
summary: India could have a major sugar supply gap by 2020, the president of the Indian Sugar Mills Association said, as stunted expansion of production will exacerbate increased usage brought about by lifestyle changes.

headline: A Kid's Guide to Humayun's Tomb
summary: A new illustrated guide, aims to bring the history and architecture of medieval Delhi alive for children.

headline: Singh Defends Retail FDI Amid Furor
summary: Prime Minister Manmohan Singh defended his government's move to allow international supermarkets and department stores to enter India by saying it would protect small-plot farmers and introduce modern technology to an industry dominated by old-fashioned storekeepers.

headline: Sweden Maintains Robust Growth
summary: Sweden's economy maintained strong growth in the third quarter, beating forecasts and likely reducing the chance of a Riksbank rate cut in December.

headline: SNC-Lavalin in Pact With Indian Companies
summary: Canadian company SNC-Lavalin Group has signed an agreement with the Ashok Piramal group and India Infrastructure Fund to build and manage road projects in India.

headline: Indian Shares End Lower Amid Political Stalemate
summary: Indian shares edged lower as investors remained cautious ahead of July-September economic data and ignored positive regional sentiment. The market was hurt also by a deadlock in Parliament.

headline: Swan Telecom Founder Shahid Balwa Gets Bail
summary: An Indian court granted bail to Shahid Balwa, co-founder of Swan Telecom and DB Realty, taking the number of people to get bail in the multi-billion-dollar telecom corruption case to 11.

headline: Belgian Inflation Soars
summary: Belgium's inflation rate rose to its highest level in almost three years in November, with the consumer price index rising 3.85% in November from the year earlier.

headline: Budget Surplus 'Herculean' Task for Australia
summary: Australia's government stuck to its goal of restoring its budget to surplus in the year starting July 1 next year, slashing spending even as warnings of an imminent European crisis continued to grow.

headline: India Expects $75 Billion Investment in Oil, Gas Sector
summary: India expects 3.90 trillion rupees ($75 billion) to be invested in its oil and gas sector from April 2012 to March 2017, the country's junior oil minister said.

headline: Asia Stocks Extend Europe-Fueled Gains
summary: Asian shares ended mostly higher after the U.S. holiday-shopping season got off to a strong start and on optimism a meeting of euro-zone finance ministers would advance a closer fiscal union to resolve the debt crisis. South Korea's Kospi gained 2.3%.

headline: Max Hypermarkets to Add 20 Large Stores in India
summary: Max Hypermarkets India plans to add 20 large-format stores by March 2014 to expand its retail operations in the country, its managing director said.

headline: Swiss Nuclear Switchoff May Curb Growth
summary: Switzerland's plans to exit nuclear power generation by 2034 will be costly for both energy companies and industry

headline: Hexaware Expects Healthy Sales Growth
summary: Hexaware Technologies expects to continue its healthy sales growth in 2012 despite global economic uncertainties, as some of the largest-ever outsourcing contracts it signed earlier this year start contributing to revenue.

headline: CapitaLand Adds China Property
summary: CapitaLand, Southeast Asia's largest property developer by market value, will jointly develop a mixed-use property project in China estimated to cost about $3.2 billion.

headline: Spanish Retail Sales Drop
summary: Spain's retail sales fell at their fastest pace in four months in October, the latest indication of a likely late-year contraction in the euro zone's fourth-largest economy.

headline: Lenders OK Air India Restructuring Plan
summary: A consortium of 26 lenders to Air India has broadly approved a plan to restructure 180 billion rupees ($3.45 billion) debt for the loss-making carrier, an aviation ministry official said.

headline: FDI Furor in Parliament
summary: The Indian Cabinet's decision to relax rules on foreign direct investment in the retail sector has come under fire from opposition parties as well as some allies of the Congress party-led government. In pictures..

headline: U.K. Mortgage Approvals Rise
summary: The number of new mortgage approvals in the U.K. rose to its highest level in almost two years in October, Bank of England data showed, but lending to businesses shrank.

headline: Facebook Regrets Merck Mix-Up
summary: Facebook took responsibility for an incident that led to a court battle between the German drug maker Merck KGaA and the U.S.-based rival Merck & Co. over the rights to a page on Facebook's website.

headline: Maruti to Buy Diesel Engines From Fiat

headline: Olympus Sets Up Corporate-Governance, Business-Revival Teams
summary: Scandal-hit Olympus said it created two internal teams this week, one on corporate governance and the other reviving its business.

headline: Acer: Possible to Break Even Despite Floods

headline: SEBI Sets Up Group to Review IPO Process
summary: The Securities and Exchange Board of India, or SEBI, has set up a panel for a complete review of the initial public offering process, the chairman of the capital markets regulator said.

headline: Proton Net Profit Down 76%
summary: Proton Holdings' net profit declined 76% in the fiscal second quarter as higher expenses at its troubled Lotus sports-car unit weighed on the national car maker.

headline: A Family Affair
summary: A look at China's leaders, past and present, and their offspring, often known as 'princelings.'

headline: India May Look at Auctioning More Broadband Bandwidth
summary: India's Department of Telecommunications may auction more bandwidth to provide wireless broadband services after the government decides on a pricing policy, the telecom secretary said.

summary: A vendor relaxes among yarns of wool, an elephant helps provide medical treatment, an Indian cricket fan waves a flag, fishermen return from work, and more.

headline: India Ministry Asks for Tax Cuts on Jet Fuel
summary: India's aviation ministry is trying to convince local state governments and the finance ministry to bring down the sales tax on jet fuel in a bid to help cash-strapped airlines cut losses, the industry's minister said.

headline: Brees Shreds Giants
summary: Favored or not, the Giants once again played like dogs, getting walloped, 49-24, by the Saints—and no words could possibly erase the doom this outing spells.

headline: South Korea CPI Rebasing Reduces 2011 Inflation
summary: The South Korean government said a regular rebasing of the consumer price index will translate to a 0.4-percentage-point downward revision in headline inflation for the full year.

headline: How to Defend the Whiz Kid
summary: The New York Rangers' young defense hasn't seen a lot of the NHL's best player; they'll get a good look on Tuesday.

headline: Testing for Public Service
summary: China's National Civil Service Exam started Sunday. This year, about one million people are competing for around 18,000 highly coveted jobs in the country's public service system.

headline: Helping a Library to Next Chapter
summary: Sally Susman contributed $50,000 to create a fiction reading room at the John Jermain Memorial Library in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

headline: Afghanistan Seeks Enduring Support
summary: Afghan officials are bringing a simple message to Western powers at an international conference on Afghanistan's future: Don't abandon us like the Russians did.

headline: After Delay, Fund Star Cleared for Launch
summary: The former Asia head of hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management said Hong Kong regulators have found allegations against himself and Highbridge baseless and that his new hedge fund has received a licence to begin operating on Dec 1.

headline: Serbs Attack Anew in Kosovo
summary: Serbs opposed to the independence of Kosovo opened fire on NATO peacekeeping troops in Kosovo, wounding dozens, in an escalation of violence that could set back Belgrade's effort to join the EU.

headline: Najib's Promises Are Off to a Poor Start
summary: A bill to regulate protests is stricter than current law.

headline: What Housing Risk?
summary: The FHA says there's nothing for taxpayers to worry about. Oh-oh.

headline: More Fuel for the Euro Zone's Fire
summary: Gasoline looks set to remain stuck between $3 and $4 a gallon. This sustained pressure on consumers couldn't come at a worse time.

headline: Can India's Congress Sell Reform?
summary: New Delhi allows FDI in retail but hasn't won the public debate.

headline: Making Splash in SoHo
summary: W.i.P., a new nightclub in the space that previously served as a storage center for the bar Greenhouse, soft-opened this month, aiming to establish itself as a spot that's equal parts high-end watering hole and sceney art gallery.

headline: Muni Market Sounds Alert
summary: Lawyers for Jefferson County, Ala., argue that holders of $3 billion in debt used to finance a sewer should be forced to wait for their money along with all other creditors during bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: Anne Jolis: Translating Afghanistan
summary: The interpreters of the U.S. Third Infantry Brigade Combat Team on America's mission, the Taliban, and the future of their country.

headline: Nomura Curtails Debt Dealings
summary: Nomura said it sharply reduced its holdings of troubled European debt and its use of a potentially risky financing technique.

headline: Waiting for Tebow to Go Splat
summary: How long can Tim Tebow continue running the ball—and taking big hits. So far, the Broncos quarterback has shown a remarkable ability to absorb punishment.

headline: Work & Family Mailbox
summary: Columnist Sue Shellenbarger answers a reader's question about grandparents who baby-sit their grandchildren.

headline: Strikes, Fleet Grounding to Hit Qantas Profit
summary: Qantas Airways forecast a steep decline in first-half profit, largely driven by costly strikes and the grounding of the Australian airline's entire fleet to force a resolution with trade unions.

headline: Cuomo Revises Proposal
summary: New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo said he is considering the idea of raising investment capital from union pension funds to help finance the reconstruction of the Tappan Zee Bridge but isn't eyeing the state's pension fund as a source of infrastructure financing.

headline: Ways to Inflate Your IQ
summary: Fluctuations in IQ scores over time underscore the brain-boosting benefits of a complex job, musical training, advanced schooling and new experiences throughout a lifetime.

headline: State Budgets Improve Slowly
summary: After four years of recession-induced tumult, states are finally getting a handle on their finances. But they are in for more lean years.

headline: NATO Airstrike Shows Widening Rift
summary: Saturday's NATO attack on two Pakistani military outposts lasted over an hour and continued after Pakistani commanders demanded the assault stop, in a sign of how far both sides are from cooperating in the Afghan border region.

headline: Facebook Targets Huge IPO
summary: Facebook is exploring raising $10 billion in an IPO that could value Facebook at more than $100 billion. It's targeting IPO dates between April and June 2012.

headline: Fouad Ajami: Egypt and the Fruits of the Pharaohs
summary: The disorder in Cairo is not the result of democracy but rather of a half-century of authoritarianism.

headline: Generic Lipitor Goes on Sale: A Users' Guide
summary: Generic versions of cholesterol-drug Lipitor can go on sale this week. Many patients look forward to the lower copayments that will bring. Others are concerned what the switch might mean for their health. A guide for consumers.

headline: The Smoldering Tenor
summary: Despite his Latinate good looks, German operatic star Jonas Kaufmann understands the limitations of beauty onstage. Mr. Kaufmann stars in the Metropolitan Opera's production of "Faust" beginning Nov. 29.

headline: Bets Against Euro Hit 17-Month High
summary: Traders placed their largest wager against the euro since June 2010, betting that Europe's sovereign-debt crisis will continue to plague the currency.

headline: Citi Ruling Could Chill SEC, Street Legal Pacts
summary: A judge rejected a $285 million deal by Citigroup to settle fraud charges, in a ruling that could have a big impact on future law-enforcement efforts against Wall Street firms.

headline: Obama, Romney Look Past Primaries
summary: The race for the White House took on the tone of a general election, with GOP candidate Mitt Romney and President Barack Obama's allies trading barbs.

headline: Proposed Air Strikes on Iran Draw Praise and Fears
summary: I applaud Jamsheed K. Choksy's Nov. 23 op-ed "How to Topple the Ayatollahs." Prof. Choksy clearly delineates the advantages of air strikes.

headline: Grain of Salt With Sales
summary: Black Friday sales need to be taken with a grain of salt, as they aren't accurate predictors of how the holiday shopping season will unfold.

headline: Do Lethal Apple Pies Imperil Soup Kitchen?
summary: Is it fitting that the Morristown, N.J., Community Soup Kitchen—a volunteer organization that has served the community for 26 years—should become a "retail" food establishment under state law?

headline: Toyota Rethinks Production
summary: Toyota's president said the car maker would consider shifting more production from Japan if the yen remains at record highs against the dollar.

headline: Singer Alleges Trade-Off to Sway Coverage
summary: Charlotte Church told a U.K. panel examining press ethics that she waived a $154,000 fee to perform at Rupert Murdoch's wedding in 1999 to gain favorable coverage in his papers. The company denied the allegation.

headline: What's News: World-Wide
summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Nov. 29, 2011

headline: Ohio State to Undergo an 'Urban' Renewal
summary: Urban Meyer, who twice retired from his previous job as football coach at Florida to devote time to family and his health, was introduced Monday as coach at Ohio State. Plus, if this lockout-shortened NBA season is like the last one, the bricks will be flying.

headline: Summit, Lions Gate in Merger Talks
summary: Summit Entertainment, the movie studio behind the "Twilight" series of vampire movies, and film and TV company Lions Gate are in merger discussions, according to people familiar with the situation.

headline: Women Pulling the Trigger
summary: Even as New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg has emerged as one of the most vigorous national voices for gun control in recent years, one group of local shooters is quietly thriving: the Women's Shooting Sports League.

headline: Barney Frank's Career in Congress
summary: Massachusetts Democratic Rep. Barney Frank, a key lawmaker on financial issues and a longtime liberal voice on Capitol Hill, said he will retire from Congress at the end of next year.

headline: Stephens: The Great Global Warming Fizzle
summary: The climate religion fades in spasms of anger and twitches of boredom.

headline: Decorated Marine Sues Contractor
summary: Two months ago Dakota Meyer was awarded the Medal of Honor. On Monday, Sgt. Meyer alleged that a defense contractor called him mentally unstable and a drinker, ruining his chances for a defense-industry job.

headline: Sony to Keep Image-Sensor Unit in Japan
summary: Sony plans to keep its lucrative image-sensor-making operations in Japan despite the yen's persistent strength, which is driving electronics makers overseas for better profit margins.

headline: Great White North Becomes a Refuge in Global Investing Storm
summary: Tired of the turbulence in the global debt markets, American investors have been pouring into Canadian government bonds.

headline: Kindle Catches Fire
summary: After more than a year of missteps by Apple's tablet rivals, at least one viable competitor, Amazon's Kindle Fire, appears to have surfaced for the popular iPad.

headline: Alpine Apartment
summary: This completely renovated three-bedroom duplex is located in an old protected building in the center of the Alpine town of Chamonix, overlooked by Mont Blanc.

headline: Justices to Weigh Overtime Pay for Drug Reps
summary: The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether pharmaceutical-sales representatives are covered by federal overtime-pay requirements.

headline: New England Has No Shot Against Indianapolis
summary: Against the spread, that is. New England is a 21-point favorite—a dangerous number historically in the NFL.

headline: Major Producers Mug Specialty Businesses
summary: It's not just Christmas trees that are subject to crony collusion between business and government in the form of "marketing programs" funded by taxes on producers ("About That 'Christmas Tree Tax,'" Review & Outlook, Nov. 14).

headline: Neiman Marcus Profit Surges
summary: Neiman Marcus Group's earnings soared 88% as the luxury department-store operator posted stronger sales and benefited from lower interest expense.

headline: Icahn Offers to Buy Commercial Metals
summary: Icahn Enterprises offered to acquire Commercial Metals in a bid that values the scrap-metal processor at roughly $1.73 billion.

headline: U.K. to Boost Rate on Bank Levy
summary: The U.K. government will increase the rate of its bank levy in a bid to raise the $3.9 billion the cash-strapped country first targeted with the tax, according to a person familiar with the matter.

headline: The Just-Say-No Crime-Busters
summary: By all means, bring the full weight of the criminal justice system down on the most violent and incorrigible wrong-doers. The others? Tell them to stop. Daniel Horan reviews "Don't Shoot."

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Ministers to Reject Pan-Europe Bank Guarantees
summary: EU finance ministers are set to reject calls from EU institutions and banking experts for a pan-European system of bank debt guarantees aimed at thawing the region's frozen long-term funding markets.

headline: A Recipe for Middle-Class Jobs
summary: The U.S. desperately needs middle-skill jobs for people who didn't go to college. Austin, Texas, has an unlikely answer for how to create them.

headline: Fukushima Manager Steps Down
summary: The manager of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant will leave his post after serving as on-site crisis manager over the past eight months due to undisclosed health problems.

headline: Stephen Pollard: No Two Ways to Fix Britain's Budget
summary: George Osborne wants a 3% spending cut. Labour wanted 2.2%. The difference is hardly Keynes vs. Hayek.

headline: Europe Pressures Banks for Loans
summary: Some European nations, struggling to find buyers for their bonds, are pressuring their own already-stressed banks to fill the gap by acting as lenders of last resort.

headline: Dark Clouds Over Bonuses at Law Firms
summary: New York law firm Cravath said it would keep its year-end bonuses to associate attorneys mostly at 2010 levels. The bonuses are only slightly higher than they were in 2009 and are still down significantly from 2007.

headline: Congo Vote Goes On With Some Violence
summary: Millions of voters cast their votes for president and parliament amid fears of widespread civil unrest, a torrential downpour in the capital, tardy poll workers and confusion over newspaper-size ballots.

headline: New Calculation: Math in Preschool
summary: Scores of preschool and kindergarten teachers across Chicago are embedding math concepts into daily classroom activities, in a promising new program that gives students a foundation for more complex math and logical-thinking skills in later grades.

headline: China Bans Ads During TV Dramas
summary: China's regulators will ban advertising during TV dramas, to encourage more cultural programs. The move is a blow to marketers who have ramped up ad spending to reach the nation's growing consumer class.

headline: ECB Keeps a Lid on Bond Buys
summary: The European Central Bank has showed no sign of abandoning its conservative approach to buying government bonds in recent days, keeping the pressure on euro-zone governments to take the lead in stemming the debt crisis.

headline: Genting Dreams of a New Vegas in Miami
summary: A Malaysian gambling company wants to build what could be the world's largest casino on prime Miami waterfront land.
